text: Glad we're mostly on the same page <@UCUSW7WVD>! My new framing was definitely inspired by some of your writings. I think my sub problem is useful by itself but not to people at parties. Basically any technical subproblem would fit that description. That's why I feel like I need to zoom out a bit. However, I agree with you on being more specific. Maybe I simply say I'm building a fully customizable email app (and keep quiet on the fact that you'll be able to build any web app with it)

elements.text: Glad we're mostly on the same page

! My new framing was definitely inspired by some of your writings. I think my sub problem is useful by itself but not to people at parties. Basically any technical subproblem would fit that description. That's why I feel like I need to zoom out a bit. However, I agree with you on being more specific. Maybe I simply say I'm building a fully customizable email app (and keep quiet on the fact that you'll be able to build any web app with it)

text:
Exactly. I think this is widely applicable advice: _"Better to start with an overly narrow description of your project than try to describe it in its full generality and lose the audience completely."_ -- <http://www.ycombinator.com/howtoapply>

There's also the question of tailoring your description to the specific party you're at. But we all wrestle with that..

How would you answer my Gmail question? To me there's no way to get someone like Gmail to adopt an entire new approach that reduces their power over users without first showing an alternative and demonstrating adoption. Show people a new thing that's more desirable than the old thing.

(Also, app stores are particularly challenging; you can't really build a powerful programmable app atop either Android or iOS. Thinking about mobile is inevitably depressing to me. If you have thoughts on how to use existing app stores I'm all ears.)

elements.text: Exactly. I think this is widely applicable advice:
"Better to start with an overly narrow description of your project than try to describe it in its full generality and lose the audience completely."

There's also the question of tailoring your description to the specific party you're at. But we all wrestle with that..

How would you answer my Gmail question? To me there's no way to get someone like Gmail to adopt an entire new approach that reduces their power over users without first showing an alternative and demonstrating adoption. Show people a new thing that's more desirable than the old thing.

(Also, app stores are particularly challenging; you can't really build a powerful programmable app atop either Android or iOS. Thinking about mobile is inevitably depressing to me. If you have thoughts on how to use existing app stores I'm all ears.)

text: Ah sorry I missed that question. My approach would be to build a competitor to gmail (potentially built as a "front end" to Gmail as you could login with that account and we'd forward to it)

elements.text: Ah sorry I missed that question. My approach would be to build a competitor to gmail (potentially built as a "front end" to Gmail as you could login with that account and we'd forward to it)

text: As far as getting around app stores, I think the ideal world would be everything be web based, which I imagine is just a matter of time. Processors get faster, web standards include more of the hardware, etc. I'm not an expert on mobile development so I don't know how realistic that is but it's my hope

text: Hey <@U5TCAFTD3>, I like it very much, especially the optimistic outlook at the end. The only thing I didn't quite get was "getting rid of the settings menu". Even if it would be a lot easier to change existing apps, having a dedicated place for the most-used settings could still be useful in my opinion. I think settings are good, the problem is just that it's almost impossible to change anything not found in the settings.

text: Yes this is a great point. The spirit of my comment was: wouldnt it be neat if changing an app was so easy that we wouldn't need a settings menu because you could just change the value of a constant somewhere? But I totally see your point that a settings menu may never be beatable for simplicity

text: Consider that even if Gmail's source was trivial to change, doing so without someway of deploying your changes wouldn't be of much value.  Software isn't just it's code, it's how it's embedded, connected to the rest of the world.

elements.text: Consider that even if Gmail's source was trivial to change, doing so without someway of deploying your changes wouldn't be of much value.  Software isn't just it's code, it's how it's embedded, connected to the rest of the world.

text: I agree with <@UCUSW7WVD> on narrow descriptions.  The problem with a general tool is seeing how the specific problem at hand fits into the general context.  Think of how often you have Googled how to do something specific at the shell knowing for sure that a clever piping of three commands is the solution you're looking for.

text: <@UAL7940NM> though strictly right about the settings menu, it's the sentiment, the sense of "where we're going we don't need roads" or "I’m trying to tell you that when you’re ready, you won’t have to."
